citation.article-title: Dyadobacter fermentans gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel gram-negative bacterium isolated from surface-sterilized Zea mays stems.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Dyadobacter fermentans sp. nov.
Dyadobacter fermentans (fer.men'tans. L. part. fermentans causing fermentation)
Morphological and chemotaxonomic characteristics are the same as those described for the genus.

This strain can grow on acetate, D- and L-arabitol, amidon, fumarate, 5-ketogluconate, glucose, glycerol, D-lyxose, malate, malonate, sucrose, tartrate, erythritol, D- and L-arabinose, D- and L-xylose, β-methylxyloside, galactose, D-glucose, D-fructose, mannose, L-sorbose, rhamnose, dulcitol, inositol, mannitol, sorbitol, methyl α-D-mannoside, methyl α-D-glucoside, N-acetyl-glucosamine, amygdaline, arbutine, aesculin, salicin, cellobiose, maltose, lactose, melibiose, saccharose, trehalose, inulin, melezitose, D-raffinose, xylitol, β-gentiobiose, D-turanose, D-tagatose, and D- and L- fucose.
It can ferment glucose and sucrose and produce acid from ribose.
This strain cannot hydrolyse agar, cellulose, gelatin or starch.
The principal fatty acids are 43∙5% 15:0iso 2-OH/16:1ω7c, 17∙5% 16:1ω5c and 16∙8% 15 : 0iso.
The type strain, NS114T, was isolated from surface-sterilized Zea mays (cv. Mo17) stem and has been deposited in the American Type Culture Collection as ATCC 700827T.
